730759f-b.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730759f-b.text:
George Washington Bridge: A northward view up the North (Hudson) Rtiver showing the cables and piers of the uncompleted structure. Manhattan is on the right and New Jersey on the left. Note the United States Navy vessels off of Riverside Drive. View No. 2 is a close up of the Manhattan base. Note here, at the left, the small lighthouse on a promontory, the historic significance of which goes back to the Revolution, as it was from here that the chains extended across the River. Apartments seen in the background form the area
known as Washington Heights.
May 10, 1930
dnift of W. A. Lucas

730762f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.
730762f-a.text:
Four square blocks of modern apartment buildings; sacrificed to make clearance for the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, at
approximately West 181st Street, in Manhattan.
Late 1930.7
Ewing Galloway.

730769f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [View of the bridge from State line between New York and New Jersey.]
730769f-a.text:
(1)
The George Washington Bridge, looking towards New York, frow the State line between New York and New Jersey.
September 29, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view emphasising the north side. Apartment houses shown are in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan.
September 29, 1932.
L. Sperr.
(No. 2, not a dry mount item).

730767f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730767f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge, in its majestic span of the Hudson River; from West 181st Street in Manhattan, to Fort Lee in New Jersey; as see looking west to the Palisades from Manhattan. An added feature of this Bridge are the two observation platforms, atop both towers.
About 1932.
Wurts Brothers.

730771f-a.text:

June 6, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

730775f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey.]
730775f-a.text:
The George Washington Bridge, a steel structure, connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey. The view is westward from Manhattan, and just south of the Bridge. Control of this engineering Rsterpieoe, is in the hands of the N.Y. Port Authority, who will charge a toll for crossing same. These 4 views are more or less similar, and are
all by the sage photographer.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.

730777f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730777f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: The Manhattan support as viewed southward on the Hudson River. Note the light house at its base. This is the last
of its kind left on the island of Manhattan.
July 19, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

730779f-b.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]
730779f-b.text:
George 4ashington Bridge: A set of 2 views southwestward from Dr. Chas. V. Paterno's estate on the east bank of the North (Hudson) River, showing this span connecting Manhattan with Jersey thru a ribhon of steel. The castlelloted structure at the left is the home of the aforementioned individual and is at this time being razed to provide an apartment site. For views see Cahrini Blvd.
Aumust 23, 1938.
Viewsl and 2
P. L. Sperr

730780f.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [View of the bridge at night from Fort Tryon Park.]
730780f.text:
The George Washington Bridge at night as photographed southwestward from Fort Tryon Park inManhattan.
1939
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Folix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.

730774f-b.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Riverside Drive.]
730774f-b.text:
(1)
The George Washington Bridge, as viewed southwestward across Riverside Drive and the Hudson River, from Fort Tryon Park. This structure which unites the two states, terminates on the far side at
Englewood, New Jersey.
June 22, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).
Ncg  N 221
(2)
The same.
July 30, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg N. 2S1
(3)
An earlier view from approximately the same vantage point, showing the spun cables connecting the pier heads prior to the suspension
of the cat--walk.
October 5, 1930.

730757f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the world's longest suspension bridge.]
730757f-a.text:
Rush Construction of World's Longest Suspension Bridge. Right, construction work on one of the piers of the great Hudson River Bridge which will be opened in 1932 at a cost of ab out 170 million. The Bridge will connect Manhattan(lower right) between 178th Street and 179th Street and Fort Lee, New Jersey(left) where another pier is shown. The distance between the two piers, from which the Bridge will be suspended, is 3,500 feet -- over twice the length of the longest suspension bridge at present
(Canden-Philadelphia span).
n.d.  Underwood and Underwood

730758f-b.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the bridge, connecting Manhattan, New York to New Jersey.]
730758f-b.text:
George WashiNton Bridge: Three views showing the construction beriod attendant to this public work that connects Manhattan, New York to Wew Jersey. The first two views are of the New York Approach
while the third is of the Jersey side.
Views: 1-2 February 1931
View : 3 August 1929
George L. Balgue

730766f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.
730766f-a.text:
(1)
The George Washington Bridge spans the beautiful Hudson River, in connecting Fort Lee N.J., to West 181st Street Manhattan. View is
looking west to the N. J. Palisades.
September 29, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The George Washington Bridge, as seen from fill near 165th Street and Riverside Drive, looking westward at Ne Jersey.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, showing the Waverly Boat Club; as seen from about 167th
Street and Riverside Drive.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
